title: Reclaiming People-Centred Development in an Age of Retrogression: Reflections on Doha Summit
content: During the World Summit for Social Development in Doha, discussions unfolded with a mix of hope, urgency, and unease. Hope, because the conversations were bold, practical, and solution-oriented. Urgency, because there is no time left for polite consensus-building when people’s lives are at stake. And unease, because even as governments reaffirm the need to place people at the center of development, the forces seeking to roll back these gains are gathering unprecedented strength. title: The Fairy Dust of Digitalisation: Why Tech Won’t Deliver Social Development
content: The second World Summit for Social Development was a spectacular event. At a moment when the very idea of multilateralism feels increasingly precarious, the summit brought together an estimated 14,000 people from across the globe. World leaders reaffirmed their commitment to eradicate poverty, drive inclusive and sustainable growth, promote decent work and strengthen adaptive social protection systems. title: China’s Trade Relations Need Reform
content: China’s export growth and record trade surplus, in a year when it has been partially shut out from US markets, signal the need to seek greater balance in its trade with other nations. Early in January, preliminary estimates of China’s trade surplus (from the General Administration of Customs of China) placed it at $1.7 trillion in 2025, as compared with $993 million in 2024. title: The Silence on Macroeconomics: A Critical Miss for WSSD II
content: The Second World Summit on Social Development, held in Doha from 4 to 6 November, was significant, marking thirty years since the first summit in Copenhagen. Yet its importance was undercut by a key omission: the discussions paid little attention to the macroeconomic frameworks that continue to constrain social development. title: The Solutions Approach of WSSD II: A Missed Opportunity to Promote Transformational Approaches to Social Development?
content: The organisers of the recently concluded Second World Summit for Social Development in Doha decided to focus on solutions to social development, not the problems.
